block.p: The effort to justify the incineration of thousands of innocent Japanese civilians casts a shadow on the meaning of the Hiroshima anniversary (''Blood on Our Hands?,'' by Nicholas D. Kristof, column, Aug. 5). The human family ought only to weep for the mass exterminations of the 20th century. Violence is not a Japanese problem or an Iraqi problem or a German or American problem. It is a human problem.

The effort to justify the incineration of thousands of innocent Japanese civilians casts a shadow on the meaning of the Hiroshima anniversary (''Blood on Our Hands?,'' by Nicholas D. Kristof, column, Aug. 5). The human family ought only to weep for the mass exterminations of the 20th century. Violence is not a Japanese problem or an Iraqi problem or a German or American problem. It is a human problem.

The historian Jonathan Glover calculates that humans have violently killed approximately one hundred million fellow human beings over the course of the 20th century, roughly 100 people per hour, seven days a week, 24 hours a day.
Rather than defend past atrocities, let us mourn our common loss and devote ourselves to understanding the social forces blinding our better angels.
